title: Mary Cain (editor)
text:
Mary Dawson Cain (August 17, 1904 – May 6, 1984) was an American <a href="newspaper%20editor">newspaper editor</a>, political activist, and gubernatorial candidate in <a href="Mississippi">Mississippi</a>. A <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>, she advocated for conservative causes and is particularly remembered for her campaigns against the <a href="Social%20Security%20tax">Social Security tax</a>. She ran for <a href="Governor%20of%20Mississippi">Governor of Mississippi</a> in 1951 and 1955, the first woman to do so.
Life.
Cain was born in <a href="Burke%2C%20Louisiana">Burke, Louisiana</a>, the daughter of Charles Goodrich Dawson and Tulula Bryant Dela Garza Dawson. She was educated in public schools in Louisiana and Mississippi, and graduated from <a href="Hillman%20College">Hillman College</a>. She married mechanic and business owner John Lambdin Cain in 1924.
Cain owned and edited "The Summit Sun", a weekly newspaper in <a href="Pike%20County%2C%20Mississippi">Pike County, Mississippi</a>, contributing "Mary Cain's Column". Cain used her paper to promote <a href="Racial%20segregation">segregation</a> and <a href="conservative">conservative</a> causes, and was particularly critical of the federal government, especially the <a href="Social%20Security%20tax">Social Security tax</a>.
Cain became the first woman ever to run for <a href="Governor%20of%20Mississippi">Governor of Mississippi</a> in 1951, when she led an unsuccessful but memorable campaign as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>. She ran again in 1955.
Cain came to national attention in 1952 when she refused to pay $42.87 in Social Security taxes, calling the program "unconstitutional, immoral and un-American". She attempted to dodge the <a href="Internal%20Revenue%20Service">Internal Revenue Service</a> by selling "The Summit Sun" to her niece for a nominal sum of $1 and closing her bank accounts. Later that year the IRS seized the paper and padlocked the door; Cain responded by cutting the chains with a hacksaw and sending them back to the agency, earning herself the nickname "Hacksaw Mary". Her tax battle went to the Supreme Court; Cain lost, but the government subsequently dropped the suit.
In 1965, she appeared in an <a href="NBC%20News">NBC News</a> documentary titled "Mississippi: A Self Portrait", where she proclaimed her support for segregation and its values, particularly in Mississippi. "I think Mississippi has done wonders with our race relations, she said. I think that is has been a marvelous thing that our Negroes has come as far as they have, and I feel no sense of guilt and I do not have to apologize for what we have done for them." Later she elaborated on her views on race, framing them on theological grounds. "Now I feel that God had a purpose in creating the races separate,” she said. I am so proud of Negroes who are proud of being Negroes. They are what God made them. And I'm proud of being White because I am what my White race has made me. I am White today because my parents practiced segregation, and I wouldn't be anything but White. And I love Negroes who wouldn't be anything but Negroes."
Cain died on May 6, 1984 at the age of 79 in <a href="McComb%2C%20Mississippi">McComb, Mississippi</a>.
